data.title: Columbia Noir #6: The Whistler on Indicator Blu-ray in May
data.text:
In May will present its sixth journey into Columbia Pictures'Â film noirÂ output, but this time taking a different path with Columbia Noir #6: The Whistler, a detour into the mysterious world of the Whistler, with a box set containing all eight films in the popular series.

Adapted from a hit radio series, each episode has the Whistler emerge from the shadows to introduce a nightmarish, twisting tale in his own sardonic manner, with the first seven films starring Richard Dix (It Happened in Hollywood).

InÂ The Whistler (William Castle, 1944), a guilt-stricken man hires a contract killer to end his lifeâ¦ but finds he cannot pull out of the deal.Â

The Mark of the WhistlerÂ (William Castle, 1944) sees a homeless man claim the money in an abandoned bank account, only to find the rightful owners on his tail.

InÂ The Power of the Whistler (Lew Landers, 1945), an amnesiac must reconstruct his dark past using only the items in his pockets.Â

Voice of the WhistlerÂ (William Castle, 1945) finds a poor nurse marry her wealthy, terminally ill patient, only for him to defy the odds and recover.

InÂ Mysterious Intruder (William Castle, 1946), a private eye becomes embroiled in a murderous race to track down a missing girl and a lost fortune.Â

The Secret of the WhistlerÂ (George Sherman, 1946) sees a young bride suspect that her new husband may have murdered his first wife.

In Dix's final film,Â The Thirteenth Hour (William Clemens, 1947), the owner of a trucking company is framed for a murder he didn't commit.

Finally, inÂ The Return of the Whistler (D Ross Lederman, 1948), Michael Duane takes the lead as a man whose fiancÃ©e is abducted on the eve of their wedding.

This essential four-disc collection marks the UK Blu-ray premiere of all eight films, and features an array of fascinating contextualising extras, including newly recorded commentaries, critical appreciations, rare archival short films, and a 120-page book. Strictly limited to 6,000 individually numbered units.

Columbia Noir #6: The Whistler will be released as a 4-disc Blu-ray box set by Indicator on 20 May 2024 at the pre-order price of Â£54.99.

INDICATOR LIMITED EDITION 4 x BLU-RAY BOX SET FEATURES:

High Definition presentations ofÂ The Whistler,Â The Power of the Whistler,Â Voice of the Whistler,Â Mysterious Intruder,Â The Secret of the Whistler,Â The Thirteenth Hour, andÂ The Return of the Whistler

Standard Definition presentation ofÂ The Mark of the Whistler

Original mono audio

Audio commentary with film historian Josh Nelson onÂ The WhistlerÂ (2024)

Audio commentary with professor and film scholar Jason A Ney onÂ The Power of the WhistlerÂ (2024)

Audio commentary with film historian Lee Gambin onÂ Voice of the Whistler (2024)

Audio commentary with film historian Jeremy Arnold onÂ Mysterious Intruder (2024)

Audio commentary with academic and curator Eloise Ross onÂ The Thirteenth HourÂ (2024)

Kim Newman on The WhistlerÂ (2024): in-depth exploration of the film series by the critic and author

Kim Newman on William CastleÂ (2024): overview of the cult filmmaker's early career as a studio-contracted director, prior to his successes as an independent showman best known for his macabre genre movies

Stuart Holmes Oral HistoryÂ (1958): rare archival audio recording of the prolific character actor in conversation with historian George Pratt

It's MurderÂ (1944): dramatised documentary, produced by Columbia Pictures for the war effort and featuring a number of cast and crew members fromÂ The WhistlerÂ film series

It's Your AmericaÂ (c. 1945): dramatised documentary focusing on soldiers returning from World War II, directed by John Ford and featuring J Carroll Naish, the antagonist inÂ The Whistler

Image galleries: promotional and publicity materials

New and improved English subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing

Limited edition exclusive 120-page book with a new essay by Tim Lucas, archival interviews with actor Richard Dix, an extract from director William Castle's autobiography, an archival article on the popularity of the radio show, new writing on the short films, and film credits

World premieres on Blu-ray

Limited edition box set of 6,000 individually numbered units for the UK
